data.title: High Contrast not achieved for debugging variables
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.15063]

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Select the "high contrast" color scheme
2.  Start debugging a node.js app, inserting a breakpoint somewhere interesting
3.  Point at an object variable

Result:

Insufficient contrast for members of type bool (blue), string (red) and number (green) on dark-grey background.   Medium-grey objects could benefit from being brighter.

![badcontrast](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2715647/26768073/136f4d80-495a-11e7-86eb-aead7168b2a1.png)

Steps to Reproduce:

2. Do 'meter reset' on cm in meteor project  (I'm not sure it is necessary as sometimes error occured when doing just 'meteor run')

Before using vscode. It had been never appeared.
If I close vsocde and run meteor, it will work without error.

Thanks

data.title: Make extension list in generated issue shorter
data.body:
Fixes #27987.

Implements the following suggestions from the issue:
- Remove some unnecessary `|`s
- Exclude extensions that only contribute themes
- Truncate publisher name

With my config, the length of the generated extension table goes from 2465 characters to 1576 characters. Which is barely under the limit, but a huge improvement.

data.title: JSON Schema does not support enums of complex objects
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|copy-syntax|atian25|0.5.1|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|auto-close-tag|formulahendry|0.4.2|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.3|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a JSON Schema.
2. Define an enum of objects for one property, ie. "enum": [{ "a" : 1, "b" : 2; }].
3. Associate the schema to a json file and insert the enum (using ctrl+space or otherwise).
4. Check problems in the json file.

I shouldn't be seeing any problems, but am getting a warning: 
{ message: 'Value is not accepted. Valid values: [{"a":1,"b":2}]' }. This is despite using ctrl+space to fill the values (and avoid typos). I've also tried it with all extensions deactivated, and it's still present.

I have independently verified this should work using the schema validator by [Newtonsoft](http://www.jsonschemavalidator.net/).

Screenshot of problem:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15162807/26766734/5a2bdc9c-4965-11e7-98dc-320ab8b8d7be.png)

Screenshot verifying json and schema:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15162807/26766724/29122eae-4965-11e7-906e-b9044822b596.png)

Files attached as txt (please rename to json) as zip isn't attaching for some reason.
[schema.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1050834/schema.txt)
[file.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1050835/file.txt)

data.title: Theming: Allow transparency in editorCursor.foreground
data.body:
With the new workbench theming we can provide cursor color with `editorCursor.foreground`, but we can't make it transparent.

Atom allows this, as shown here:
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/44252/25010687/db628668-2038-11e7-9a7e-0ec46e0bf599.png)

But VSCode doesn't:
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/44252/25010674/d592860c-2038-11e7-865d-5f4f898187dc.png)

**Feature request:** allow using ARGB for cursor color.

data.title: Breakpoints not hit when debugging jest with inspector
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Win 10

I had existing nodejs project setup with debug launch configuration as below:

```
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Jest Tests",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}\\node_modules\\jest\\bin\\jest.js",
            "args": [
                "-i"
            ],
            "preLaunchTask": "build",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "internalConsoleOptions": "openOnSessionStart",
            "outFiles": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/dist/**/*"
            ],
            "envFile": "${workspaceRoot}/.env"
        }
```

When I debug with node 6.10.3 the latest LTS version which is recommend for VScode the debugging works correctly.  Output command generated by vscode shown below:
```
Debugging with legacy protocol because Node.js v6.10.3 was detected.
node --debug-brk=31454 --nolazy node_modules\jest\bin\jest.js -i
```
However, I updated to node 8 and ran the same launch configuration and stopped hitting the breakpoints. Output of command generated:
```
Debugging with inspector protocol because Node.js v8.0.0 was detected.
node --inspect=11120 --debug-brk node_modules\jest\bin\jest.js -i 
Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:11120/5bc05720-def6-451b-8658-fe128d2ea624
For help see https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector
(node:7960) [DEP0062] DeprecationWarning: `node --inspect --debug-brk` is deprecated. Please use `node --inspect-brk` instead.
(node:7960) [DEP0062] DeprecationWarning: `node --inspect --debug-brk` is deprecated. Please use `node --inspect-brk` instead.
```

My debug configuration is a little unconventional/more complex than normal use case since i'm using VScode debugger to invoke jest library which then dynamically loads test files as opposed to the more normal scenario of directly targeting the entry point to server startup or library file.

I think it would be nice to start with smaller project to see if I could reproduce but this is in a simpler scenario without Jest involved but this is the info i have now.

data.title: Snippet completion not triggering code formatting when editor.formatOnType: true
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Wndows 10 CU

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Install the PowerShell extension and set the following user settings:
```
    "editor.formatOnType": true,
    "powershell.codeFormatting.openBraceOnSameLine": false
```
2. To test the settings type the following `if (1) {<enter>` you should see PowerShell's code formatter move the opening curly to the next line (and complete the closing curly).
3. Now try this with a PowerShell snippet which uses K&R style braces.  Type 'if' and select the if statement snippet.  Fill in the condition with `1` and tab to inside the statement.  Notice that none of this triggers the "formatOnType" signal to the extension.  Now technically, yes the user did not type the `{` and if the user would delete and retype the `{` the formatOnType would kick in.  But that is a major PITA especially when completing constructs like try/catch/finally.  

Is there a way you could make formatOnType work with snippets?  I can't believe PoweShell is the only language where folks don't want the "default formatting" you get with snippets.  If VSCode would do this then folks could use the built-in snippets **and** get the formatting style they prefer.

data.title: baseUrl and paths setting in jsconfig.json is not working with .vue files
data.body:
Hi all

I'm using VS Code with Vue.js, I'm trying to setup VS Code to be able to display valid/invalid path of the files

Using following setting I can get correct valid/invalid sign (red underline below invalid path) but with .vue files, I only get invalid signs (both relative path and specified paths in `"compilerOptions"."paths"`

How to setup *jsconfig.json* or any other settings to make this working? Please guide

Thanks

*Path*
```
|-jsconfig.json
+-src
|    +-components
|    |    |-Foo.js
|    |    |-Foo.vue
|    |    |-entry.js
```

*jsconfig.json*
```json
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "checkJs": true,
        "module": "es2015",
        "target": "es6",
        "baseUrl": ".",
        "paths": {
            "Components": [ "./src/components" ]
        }
    }
}
```

*entry.js*
```js
// no errors, Foo.js can be resolved
import F1 from 'Components/Foo'
// no errors, Foo.js can be resolved
import F2 from './Foo'
// errors, no Fo.js anyway
import F3 from 'Components/Fo'
// errors Foo.vue cannot be resolved
import F4 from 'Components/Foo.vue'
// errors Foo.vue cannot be resolved
import F5 from './Foo.vue'
```

> tsc version: 2.3.4

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10
- `tsc` Version: 2.3.4

data.title: "No configurations" when create new .net core console project
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VSCode
1.1. _Please read below_
2. Install .NET core sdk
3. Open VSCode
4. Execute `dotnet new console`
5. Execute `dotnet restore`
6. Execute `dotnet run`
7. Successfully see "Hello world" message
8. Not be able to debug project in VSCode because of "No configurations" message in configurations listbox on Debug pane. It differs from step 3 of tutorial https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/getting-started/with-visual-studio-code where there are already 2 configurations.

I have to notice i tried to compile test *.cs file between steps 1 and 2 (after install VSCode but before install .NET Core SDK, opened VSCode, examined it, didnt know i need to .NET Core SDK at that moment). I was shown a bar "Required assets to build..." (if i not mistaken) i clicked Yes, it installed C# Extensions but wrote some error in end. Sadly i don't remember what exact error. If it is saved in any log - i'd be gladly attach it to this post. Maybe it is the matter.

data.title: Include announcement section for extension authors
data.body:
Sometimes extension authors like me at `settings-sync` need to announce something, which may large chunk of users wont care but some users though. Hence allow authors to interact with users by showing announcements.

Currently there is not way other then that I am showing the message upon the code start and users takes it as spam or whatever.
When they click on the message, link should be opened, or the message can have multiple buttons.

If there is announcement section in the extension with a notification badge in the extensions will allow users to view them anytime, unlike they are doing right now to close the information message box every time.




// cc @Tyriar (https://github.com/shanalikhan/code-settings-sync/issues/335#issuecomment-305996633)

data.title: Added editor.urlClickable setting to enable/disable clickable URL
Find in files and goto anything don't work on large folders
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Hi,

For those of us unfortunately enough to have to work with a large codebase with lots and lots and lots of files, vscode can't index files for ctrl-P and find in files takes an entire minute to execute.

The equivalent operations in sublime take a tenth of the time or less. ctrl-p to find a file by name in sublime is almost instant even on large projects. Even the vim python goto anything plugin is faster.

- VSCode Version: 1.3.1 
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a large codebase (e.g. linux kernel or unreal engine source directory)
2. Ctrl - P goto anything on a filename known to exist

data.title: There is no way to open a folder with a specific file opened and active
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.12.2
- OS Version: Win10 x64

I tried to ask this [question on stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44123722/vscode-opening-a-folder-and-a-file-from-the-same-routine/44350415#44350415) but there were no single response for two weeks. Seems like this is a very specific question that only VSCode team can answer.

The code below will open the folder but not the file:
```TS
commands.executeCommand('vscode.openFolder', 
                        Uri.parse('E:\\dev\\proj'))
        .then(() => commands.executeCommand('vscode.open',
                                            Uri.file('E:\\dev\\files\\file.json'));
```

Yes I know why. After opening the folder the rest of the code is irrelevant as the extension host process is terminated. But this means that there is no way of opening a folder with a specific document opened.

This is a limitation that probably may be easily addressed in the `openFolder` implementation. For example an additional optional parameter `activeDocumentUri`.

As a work around I had to load document on VSCode loaded. It works but it's not elegant, slow and flickering. And, for this I had to configure the extension activation for as soon as possible - the activation technique that is officially discouraged in the VSCode documentation:

>...please use this activation event in your extension only when no other activation events combination works in your use-case.

data.title: Settings with enum show redundant suggestion docs
data.body: In the below case, "Controls whether snippets are shown ...." is the comment on the `editor.snippetSuggestions`. The suggestion list shows all possible enum values. The default one has the docs "Default value", the others get the same comment as the setting which is not useful at all. The completion provider from the settings view should not send docs for the enum values.

data.title: Base64 and line column limitation?
data.body:
In this recent version, I noticed that some longer base64 encoded strings didn't allow me to pan to the end of the line. When opening the file, the line wrap is turned on, when I turn line wrap off, I cannot navigate to the end of those lines using the arrow keys. I believe the data is still all there, just causes navigation issues. It seems perhaps this is a limitation in the number of columns? The color coding does not display the same as other shorter lines, so I don't know if it isn't recognized properly or just isn't displaying all of the data.

I have included a sample of one giving me trouble.
[base64-vscode-issue.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1050057/base64-vscode-issue.zip)



- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16199
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.18.0|
|json-tools|eriklynd|1.0.2|
|vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview|hnw|0.0.4|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. load the base64.html included in the zip in this VSCode version.
2. The line including the base64 data when line wrapping is turned off cannot be navigated to using the arrow keys.

data.title: Too many issues don't include extension list because of char limit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (f977399d58f7b64db35047fafe0c6e59e15f11d5, 2017-06-02T10:45:30.209Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: the listing length exceeds browsers' URL characters limit
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install a... reasonable... number of extensions (in my case, 64)
2. Attempt to open an issue
3. See that the extensions aren't included because the URL char limit was exceeded

[Query for all of these issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20%22browsers%27%20URL%20characters%20limit%22)

The extension list is often useful on issue reports. Here are some ways we can mitigate this.

- Don't add the unnecessary leading and trailing `|`s to each extension
- Don't escape the `|` character in the grid, to save 4 characters per extension (with above)
  - This works but apparently isn't a good idea. Maybe not reliable in every browser.
- Truncate the extension list
  - Kind of defeats the purpose of including it
  - Maybe "Report Issues" button also opens an editor with the full list for the user to copy/paste
- Don't include extensions which only contribute themes, which are probably less useful in issue reports
  - This is easy and probably the most impactful. I have 17 theme extensions installed.
- Truncate the publisher name, since it's only needed to disambiguate some extensions with the same name
- Strip vowels...
